Ok, it was a stupid path error in Matlab=85.
Thanks for your kindness.
But =
now=85.
I've compiled cantera 1.7.1 with gcc 3.3 (setting a `minimal' pytho=
n installation!) and 
everything seemed fine. But running the tutorial `tut=
1.m', I had this error: 



 Traceback (most recent call last):
   File "./=
.cttmp1179929443.pyw", line 1, in ?
     from ctml_writer import *
 ImportE=
rror: No module named ctml_writer
 
??? 

*********************************=
***************
                Cantera Error!                  
**********=
**************************************


Procedure: get_XML_File
Error:   c=
annot open ./gri30.xml for reading.Note, this error indicates a possible 
c=
onfiguration problem.

Error in =3D=3D> Solution.Solution at 30
doc =3D XML=
_Node('doc',src);

Error in =3D=3D> GRI30 at 22
  s =3D Solution('gri30.cti=
','gri30');

Error in =3D=3D> tut1 at 12
gas1 =3D GRI30

>> 

What's wrong =
now?

Thanks 
 



--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, David Goodwin <dgoodwin@=
...> wrote:
>
> The warnings resulting from the -arch i386 flag are not a p=
roblem. By  
> default, python tries to build a universal binary. This warn=
ing just  
> means that your compiled code will run on ppc architectures, b=
ut not  
> i386 ones.
> 
> The file setup.m is generated and then later rem=
oved in the build  
> process. Actually all it does is change to the 'cante=
ra' directory  
> and then invoke 'buildux.m' to build the Cantera toolbox.=
 If Matlab  
> can't find the setup.m file, check that the current director=
y is on  
> the Matlab search path.
> 
> One thing to be aware of on the ma=
c: Matlab R2006b for the PowerPC  
> architecture is compiled with g++ 3.3,=
 and so all of Cantera must be  
> compiled with this version of g++ too to=
 use it in Matlab.  On the  
> other hand, Python is compiled with g++ 4.x,=
 and Cantera must be  
> built with this compiler version to use it in Pyth=
on. What this means  
> is that if you want to use Cantera in both Python a=
nd Matlab, you  
> need to build two separate versions.
> 
> On the Intel i=
386 platform, Matlab R2006b is compiled with g++ 4.x,  
> and this problem =
doesn't arise.
> 
> Dave
> 
> 
> 
> On May 21, 2007, at 8:30 AM, agentesilv=
ia wrote:
> 
> > I still haven't been able to install Cantera but I admit t=
hat in  
> > this days I've been quite
> > busy=85
> > As I've said before =
there is no `setup.m' script in the Cantera/ 
> > matlab folder but looking=

> > better I've seen an error in the python building procedure that  
> > =
occurs just before the
> > Matlab building procedure: it seems that a wrong=
  `=96arch i386' is  
> > issued to the g++
> > compiler just before the co=
rrect `-arch ppc' and this generates a  
> > lot of errors=85
> >
> >
> >

=
